sp.p: No, nor hardly a place in the other World, in Hell or Heaven, but what ſhe helps to purchaſe. You may ſend your Venture by her to which you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: That's true Lucidore; but I believe thou only keep'ſt a Correſpondence in the Lower Region.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I do ſo: It was always my Fortune to keep company with ſuch as you are, all Merchants of that place: I do not think yet amongſt us all, we have intereſt enough
to make one Bill of Exchange ſo good as to paſs there.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: There's not one of a thouſand that goes about to try till fifty or threeſcore, nor ſo much as think of it; the Seas are very rough thither, and troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, hang't; and one ſhall be ſure to be pleaſure-ſick all the way, and muſt be ſtill taking of bitter Potions to expel the groſs humors of our inclinations; not one Cordial allow'd of; live or die, ſink or ſwim, not one ſatisfaction to be had till the Voyage is ended: I am not old enough yet to think of Faſting and Prayer,; when I have ſome years over my head, I ſhall begin to do as other Grave ones have done before me, leave thoſe Vices that will no longer keep me company, and think of Heaven out of neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, I dare ſwear, thou wilt not endeavour to go thither, till thou art a Criple both by diſeaſes and time, if Death will let thee live ſo long.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I believe thou would'ſt be as glad as I, that thy life was Copy-hold-Land, that as one were out, thou mighteſt renew another.
sp.l: I hate ſuch Fools, us cannot be content
With pleaſures which that World to this hath lent.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: Act IV. Scene I.
div.stage: Enter Lotharicus paſſing one way, and Euryalus another.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Ha! my deareſt Friend Lotharicus! what unexpected accident of Fortune has given me this happineſs at Lyons?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Her moſt malicious one to me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How? Does our meeting, after ſo long an abſence, prove ſo unwelcome? Time has a changing power over all things then I ſee.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Do not injure ſo much that friendſhip I have preſerv'd ſo faithfully, and will continue to my Grave, that little time my griefs will let me live.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I fear Marcelia's dead, and dare not ask: The ſadneſs of thy look confirms it to me.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: She is indeed; and I, that Death no longer can out-live.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Poor Siſter! Poor Marcelia!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You need not grieve, my Lord, ſhe's only dead to me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Can you believe I can be ſo inſenſible of looſing in a Siſter, what you ſo much lament the loſs of in a Miſtris? If ſhe had perfections that rendred her worthy of your ſorrow, they have as juſt a claim to mine.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Oh, dear Euryalus, it is not the death ſhe ows to Nature makes me ſad; it is her death to me, and all the Vows ſhe made me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
Loth.
sp.p: I give them not that name; but I, with joy, would empty all my veins, and let life out, ſo that my knowledge gave my words the Lye.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Grown falſe without a Cauſe?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I ſay not ſo; I will not make her Accuſation more guilty then it is.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I underſtand not this myſterious Language; if you have baſely given her reaſon for to change, condemn not the effect of your own Act; but draw, and juſtifie your injuring me in her.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p:
She has a cauſe from her Ambition; but my
Love was never yet ſo Criminal to give her any: You are like to have the King your Brother; that will render you I ſuppoſe contented, though it make your friend ſtill miſerable.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How, the King!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Yes: I give not this account for fear of fighting; you know I dare, and can, defend my life, though now death would become ſo welcome, I ſhould unwillingly reſiſt it.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Ne're think a Crown can come in competition with my friendſhip; I love my Sov'reign as a Loyal Subject, will give my Life and Fortunes to preſerve his Rights, and him: This is my duties Obligation: But I had rather give Marcelia to thy Arms, then ſee her plac'd upon his Throne; nor ſhall ſhe ſit there and triumph over thy injur'd joys.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I cannot wiſh, my generous friend, that you ſhould make your ſenſe of my unhappineſs, an injury to your Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I'le ſink 'em all, but I'le reſtore thee to thy loſt contentment. I'le teach her ignorant Soul, that Acts of Honor is the Nobleſt greatneſs: I had rather have her live in Fame for Virtue when ſhe's dead, then in a Title.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Pray force not her inclinations: I had rather ſtill be miſerable, then make her ſo from your Power. Gifts of conſtraint, though in themſelves the higheſt bleſſing, are burthenſome: Her perſon, without her heart, can be no happineſs; and both, I know you cannot give me the poſſeſſion of.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: No more, my friend. How long do you intend to ſtay in theſe parts?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: But till to morrow: My thoughts are reſtleſs, and I follow them.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How far do you intend to travel?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Till I arrive at my wiſh'd journeys end.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What place is that?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: 'Tis Death, 'tis Death, my Friend: till then I'le rove about the World, and give my ſelf no conſtant habitation.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My Brother is come to Lyons, I hear; I will go write him word how falſe Lotharicus is proved. Go, ſend the Page where I bid you.

sp.speaker: Deſha.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: What ſtrange effects of Fortune do I prove!
How variouſly ſhe in my life doth move!
A Prince ſo brave, and in his Power ſo great,
Forc'd to beg favors humbly at my feet:
She never for thy glory more could do,
Then ſhe in that, Marcelia, did for you.
Pride could not raiſe, nor ſwell my hopes more high,
Then ſhe has given me Power to ſatisfie:
Nor can ſhe bring my heart to more diſtreſs,
Then ſhe has done in all my happineſs:
Then bribes me with a Crown to be content,
And makes Ambition prove Loves Monument.
But love, if true, did never Power know,
That greater, then it ſelf, could ever grow;
But that of Heaven; when it within the Soul
Does monſtrous prove, and Virtue would controul.
No, no, I ſtill muſt love whilſt I have breath;
Nothing can give my paſſion date, but death.
But that Lotharicus mayn't pleaſure take,
To think that his doth ſleep, and mine doth wake;
I'le force my courage, give me to thee King,
Though I ſhall be a heartleſs offering:
And on a Throne in ſecret mourn that Fare
Deſtroy'd his Love, and rais'd me to ſuch State.
As Princes ought, I then will act my part,
Not make my face proſpective to my heart;
Nor give the Kings contentment cauſe to doubt,
When his confin'd, my Love does wander out:
My griefs and paſſions all ſhall inward burn;
The brave, their bodies, makes their troubles Urn.

div.head: Scene 3. Enter Perilla and Arcaſia.

sp.speaker: Arcaſ.
sp.p: This fine Evening, methinks, ſhould fill the Garden full of company.

div.p: Ha! what have we here? A Knight of the Sun upon my life.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, he goes for an Outlandiſh Lord.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Prethee what's his name?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Moriphanus.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Oh, I know him now, at leaſt in Character: he ſeeks to be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You are much deceiv'd, it is to be my Maſter: The firſt time of his Viſit he ſpeaks all Matrimony, and left the diſcourſe of Love for the ſecond Interview: Marriage is the Captain, I will aſſure you, of his diſcourſe, and Love the Lievtenant.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p:
Nay, 'tis well if affection has any office in buſineſs of that kind; for there is nothing ſpeaks a Gallant now ſo ill-bred, as Marrying and Loving both in a place. But prethee let's make towards him, for I long to be cenſuring your Servant: Perhaps I may find more Merit in him then report ſpeaks, for that ſeldome knows any meanin
diſparagement, or praiſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If your curioſity be ſo great, you ſhall go by your ſelf, for I'm reſolv'd he ſhall not ſee me.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: If his company be ſo troubleſome, the moſt certain way to be-rid of it, is to marry him; and at the preſent put on your Mask, and that will ſecure you: for I muſt go that way and meet him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee what's the matter you laugh ſo exceedingly?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I am conceited you us'd your Servant very roughly when he waited on you laſt: Confeſs, did not you make your ſervants beat him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why ſhould you think ſo prethee?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: By the trimming of his Suit with that deep Blew and Black: upon my Conſcience it is an Embleme of ſome favours of yours in that kind; for he looks like one that would be cudgell'd, put off his hat, and give thanks.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, I dare ſwear for him, he would, as ſubmiſſively as any man, take a beating, if any one would beſtow the pains to give it him.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Well, I am moſt ſtrangely taken with the Mounſieur, as I live; I'd give a hundred Piſtols he were in love with me: My Doctor tells me I am going into a Conſumption; but I dare ſwear his company but one two moneths would cure me. O moſt incomparable Don Quixot! what faces and poſtures he has!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee let us go, thou haſt laugh'd enough; and if thou hold'ſt thy humor any longer, thou wilt put me into the ſame vein, and that will make me be look'd on as a mad Widdow.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: The more mad, the more faſhionable; as long as thou art ſure thy Husband is ſafe enough, for ever coming back again to uſe thee worſe by taking of it ill, thou need'ſt not care.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What would I give now that my Year of Mourning were as much worn out as my Melancholly?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have I not ſeen you before, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That Queſtion you muſt anſwer your ſelf; examine your memory, and give account to your knowledg: But if you have ſeen me before, and have forgot me, I ſhall take it inconceiveably ill, that you ſhould have turn'd me out of your head as long as the room was empty.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What fine expreſſions theſe Ladies have for any thing they ſpeak of, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O yes, my Lord, they are ſo us'd to good Language, they can call you a Fool in a Complement, and you ſhall be never the wiſer for it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not the wiſer for it, ſayeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: No, not one jot I'faith.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Do you remember as yet?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, upon my Honor, I can't call to mind neither your face, nor hers in the Mask.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Then your Lordſhip knows a face no better in a Vizard, then out of it. Are you not acquainted with out names neither?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I ſwear upon the Title of a Lord: But pray Ladies, do me that high favour to tell me what I may call you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Why, we will give you leave to be our God-father; call us what you pleaſe; but we dare not truſt you with our Names, you are ſo great a Gallant: Shall we Perilla?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is ſhe my dearly beloved Miſtris Perilla?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I thought as much; no ſooner know her name, but taking away her reputation: You are gotten into the perfect Road of the Town I ſee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am Perilla, ſince I am diſcover'd, but not your Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By my Honor, I'le ſwear before all the Judges in the Kingdome, you are, and ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What, whether I will or no? Pray how many Miſtriſes more has your deſerving Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not in poſſeſſion, but in report; for a right Gallant never keeps account in that kind upon truth, but as his humor ſerves him for boaſting, and his memory to repeat over a good long Catalogue of Ladies names.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Be ſure to reckon, my Lord, that none of the reſt of the Modes of the Town may give in a larger Bill of Ladies favors; for if you do, you are loſt if you think of Marriage with her; for ſhe has ſworn whoſoever ſhe makes her Husband, ſhall have bin as much, if not more, the Favorite of her Sex, then any.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, I can be as much as the beſt then in their eſteem.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Can be? that's not enough, there's no glory to be had in that by talking upon ſuppoſition: You muſt ſay you have bin.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, you will not confeſs then how many Miſtriſſes you have had, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If you examine me upon Oath, I muſt; for my Conſcience is very tender.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Upon Oath? you may be confident I do.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then truly I muſt needs ſay, I have had all the Ladies almoſt in the Suburbs, and City, from the Bib to the Furr'd Gown, lay aſide all thoughts of their Honor and Virtue for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, your Lordſhip has gained much upon my affection, by this acknowledgment of the general favor you have had amongſt us: I'le have your Miſtriſſes poll'd, and if no young Blade bring me a larger Bill of Fare out of the Country, 'tis ten to one but you ſhall know my mind in a week or two.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's the Widdow I told thee of; Moriphanus is her Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He ſhall be hang'd before he ſhall have her; I could almoſt love her enough to Marry her my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, ſhe's very rich too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Double temptations! I am reſolv'd I'le get acquainted with her; and if ſhe and I can agree,'tis odds but I ſhall have a ſting at Matrimony before I die.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, Arcaſia, let us leave the Garden now, the Air is ſharp, and if I ſtay longer, I am afraid my Love will catch cold.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: What, when the Fire's by?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It cannot indeed, Madam; if you mean me, I'le ſtay as long as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I wont venture it longer; I find it not well already.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, praeter Lucid. and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, Peregrine, let us follow that day-ſtar.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Du-Prette and 3 Villains.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: I am mad that Philampras is not to be found.

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Why, you know it was not to be done till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: That's true; but the wind may ſerve before that time, and then he's gone: Now we may be ſure of him; he muſt come this way from the place he ſups. Be ſure that you diſpatch him.

sp.speaker: 2 Vill.
sp.p: Fear not; we'll make him ſafe enough for ever riſing in judgment againſt you in this world, what e're he does in the next.

div.stage: Enter Lotharicus, and two lighting him with Torches.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Here he comes.

div.stage: The Villains aſſault him, and the men with Torches run away: Lotharicus draws to defend himſelf.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I would willingly die, but not by the hands of Villains.

div.stage: He fights bravely, kills one of the Villains; they wound him in many places, and he falls.

sp.speaker: 3 Vill.
sp.p: He's gone to Heaven or Hell, and has took one of us with him for his Attendance.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Are you ſure he's dead?

sp.speaker: 3. Vill.
sp.p: I, ſure enough, unleſs he has more lives then one.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: For fear he ſhould not, I'le give him my laſt bleſſing.

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Hold; he's dead I'le warrant (Pulls out a Piſtol. you; and the noiſe of that going off, will bring in company, and betray us: If you are not ſatisfied, we'll open two or three Caſements more to let his Soul paſs out by; but 'tis unneceſſary.

sp.speaker: Hark;
sp.p: I hear a noiſe; let's fly; we ſhall be taken.

div.stage: (They go back to wound him again, and hear a noiſe.

sp.speaker: 3 Vill.
sp.p: What ſhall we do with our dead companion?

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Leave him, he is not known here.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Meraſpas and Philampras, and two other men with Torches.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray let us make all the haſt we can: I have bin all this Evening to find you or your Lord out.

sp.speaker: Meraſ.
sp.p: Had not your buſineſs bin of ſuch high importance to my Lord, as you ſay, I would have borrow'd an hours time longer to have drank with my friends here.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Another time will do as well: we will go with you as far as the houſe, and there take our leaves; to morrow we'll meet again.

sp.speaker: Meraſ.
sp.p: I wonder what it is a clock?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Between eleven and twelve.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: What's that lies yonder?

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Ha! a Gentleman kill'd.

sp.speaker: Meraſ.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs my Lord. (Goes to him and looks. O, it is my Lord! It is my Lord that's murthered! Oh curſed Villains that have done this, and curſed I that was not with him to have hope to defend his life, or loſt my own in endeavouring of it! What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: There is no remedy now, poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Meraſ.
sp.p: Pray help me take up his Body, and carry it home.

div.stage: (Exeunt with Body of Lotharicus. Scene changes to a Garden.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Calinda and Ericina.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.p: Are you reſolv'd ſtill to give up your ſelf to ſo much ſadneſs? Is it ſo great a wonder to find men falſe, that you no better are prepar'd, from reaſonable expectation, to meet this change and common trouble?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: It is true, Ericina, our afflictions do uſually receive abatement from not being ſingle Sufferers; but love admits not of allays, like other ills; nor is that humor (in my mind) ſo generally to be boaſted of: Beſides, Love, when it firſt takes Poſſeſſion of our hearts, deprives us of our Reaſon; and that's the chief reſiſting ſtrength, by which we oppoſition make againſt all other accidents of Fortunes malice.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.p:
I cannot think a Paſſion by Gods and Men ſo Deified, can carry in it ſo much deſtructive danger; for if it robs our Souls of Reaſon, it makes us like to Beaſts: And certainly Heaven ne're deſign'd that Metamorphoſis, from whence we have receiv'd the higheſt proof of that All-conquering Paſſion: Beſides, ſome with their Reaſon make their Choice, and what it does approve, it may
ſubſiſt with, or baniſh it, if it too far intrude: That Reaſon is very weak and ſluggiſh, that ſuffers and Paſſion to grow ſo ſtrong as to ſupplant it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I do not wiſh thee ſo much ill as 'tis unhappily to Love, or elſe I ſhould be glad to ſee how you would rule your inclinations, which I confeſs you mannage well in ſuppoſition.
sp.l: —Would mine were governed by fancy too;
I, Player-like, could raign as well as you.
We can, unmov'd, hear others ſufferings tell,
Which, if our own, we ſhould not bear it well.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: You can no trouble have but what is mine;
My love does make my ſhare as great as thine.
Unkind Calinda, what is't you intend?
To puniſh your falſe Lover in your Friend.
Can his inconſtancy make you deſpiſe,
That friendſhip which you once ſo much did prize?
If you ſo great injuſtice will allow,
Ne're cenſure him; he did not break his Vow:
And who the ſelf-ſame Errors will commit,
In prudence ought in others pardon it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You of injuſtice talk, whilſt only I
Find from you both ſo much you fain would die.
Friendſhip and Love to me are cruel grown;
I wiſh to Heav'n that I had neither known.
Were yours true, you would not mine ſuſpect,
Our doubt grows ſtrongeſt from our own defect.
You on my Love a blemiſh fain would throw,
That in your change you might leſs guilty ſhow.
Thoſe that are wiſe do ſetting Suns forſake,
And with the riſing ones their friendſhips make.
You know who 'tis has ſet his heart on fire;
Improve your int'reſt e're the flame expire.
Love that plays Truant once without a cauſe,
Will ſtill an Out-law be to Honor's Laws:
And days, whoſe mornings do appear moſt bright,
Are often over-caſt before 'tis night.
If ſhe his ſeeming paſſion entertain,
His half-made vows will coſt his eyes ſome rain.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: She cannot greater ſhow'rs for Love let fall,
Then I ſhall do for friendſhips Funeral.
Calinda, by my death you ſoon will know,
Whither to that I have bin true or no:
Then I am ſure that you will grow more juſt,
And ſhed ſome tears for your unkind miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If that can cure thy griefs my doubts have bred,
I'le make my eyes another Deluge ſhed,
Dear Ericina, can y' a pardon give,
To an offence makes me unfit to live?

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: I can forgive much more then you can do:
Love, in that kind, ne're yet a limit knew.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I grieve to think I ſhould a debt contract,
Of which I cannot pay the Int'reſt back.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: And I am ſad to ſee your heart poſſeſt
Still with that Love, which gives your thoughts no reſt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thy charming voice would make them calmer grow.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: I'd ſing, and ne're give off, if I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sing then that Song my humor ſuits and mind,
I'le ſit down here, if thou wilt be ſo kind.

div.stage: She ſits down, and leans melancholly upon her arm.

sp.speaker: Eric.

lg.l: Oh, you powerful Gods, if I muſt be,
An injur'd Off'ring to Love's Deity,
Grant my revenge, this Plague on men,
That Women ne're may love agen:
Then I'le with joy ſubmit unto my Fate,
Which by your Juſtice gives their Empire date.
Who moſt is pleas'd when he can moſt deſtroy:
O! let the World no longer govern'd be.
By ſuch a Blind and Childiſh Deity;
For if you Gods be in your Power ſevere,
We ſhall adore you not from love, but fear.
But if you'l his Divinity maintain
O're men, falſe men, confine his • o •• 'ring raign;
And when their Hearts Love's greateſt torments prove,
Let that not pity, but our laughter move.
Thus ſcorn'd and loſt to all their wiſhes aim,
Let Rage, Deſpair, and Death, then end their flame.

sp.p: 'Tis very late, my dear Calinda, and we had beſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It may be ſo, for time does ſlowly paſs,
That runs by high Afflictions Hour-glaſs.

div.head: Scene 6. Enter Euryalus reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: It thou had'ſt ſuch reaſon for thy change, I do not blame thee then, Marcelia; I would I had receiv'd thy Letter ſooner, e're Lotharicus and I had parted, I would have juſtified thou Nobly did'ſt to ſlight him, and entertain the Kings Addreſs, ſince he ſo baſely left thee for another; nor ſhall he ſcape the puniſhment of his Perjuries, for I will follow him to give him death.

div.stage: Enter Du-Prette, and two Villains fighting.

sp.speaker: 1. Vill.
sp.p: Did'ſt thou think to make us do thy work, and cheat us of our wages? we purſu'd thee hither to Lyons to give thee death for thy deceit.

div.stage: Enter Euryalus paſſing, and two Footmen.

sp.speaker: Du-Fr.
sp.l: Oh Lotharicus, Lotharicus! thy murder is reveng'd. Oh Heaven! how conſtantly you ſtill purſue.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Ha! what art thou that talk'ſt of Lotharicus murder? Tell me, or I will take that remnant of thy life away, and by thy words, hoſt that black guilt upon it? Speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Sit, 'tis not the threat of Death can force me to confeſs. ſince I ſhall make my life, by doing it, a forfeiture to Juſtice: But from repentance and remorſe I tell—my name's Du-Prette, and I know you to be my Lord Euryalus: I'le ſay no more whilſt Witneſſes are by; now take my life, and if you think it fit; or if you let me longer live, I will inform you all I know; that which ſhall give your Courage and your Sword new edge, and Noble work.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Help carry him off.

div.head: Scene 7. Enter Lucidore and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That little Trumpeter, Cupid, has ſo perpetually ſounded in my thoughts the Widdows Perfoctions; her Wit, her Beauty, and her Wealth, as he has caus'd an uproar in my heart, and ſome of my own Subjects has liſted themſelves Souldiers under her Command.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Which prethee are turn'd Rebels?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
My Will, my Inclinations, my Covetouſneſs, and my Vanity, to take her from the reſt of my Servants; and they ſo •• outly fight my former reſolutions, and my reaſon, that, hang me, I believe they'l get the day, and tumble me head-long into a Married Life, and make me grow
grey, and grave, with a Whither-go-ye, ſqualling Kitlings, and Curtain Lectures.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Certainly thou art a ſtrange lover of Hell, that thou wilt be running into it before thy time.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, you miſtake; Marriage is a preparative for another place, both by the mortification of it, and the honeſty.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Rival has bin to ſee the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'le Rival his Coxcomb if he comes any more there. Do you hear Sir?— (Turns to Moriphanus. I am inform'd you are the Widdow Perilla's ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I ſcorn your words; I her ſervant! I'd have you to know I think to make her my Wife, and ſhe thinks to make me her Husband. I her ſervant!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, whatſoe're ſhe thinks, you had beſt think of her no more, or win her now by your Sword.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Win her? did not I tell you juſt now, I have won her already? and I am not ſuch a Fool to fight for any thing that's my own: Stake another Lady to her, and have at you who ſhall have both.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But then you ſhall fight.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shall fight?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I ſhall fight, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, I thought you had bin a man of that Authority, to have made me fight whither I would or no. I tell you then, Sir, I love her ſo well, I'd ſooner be beaten for her ſake, then fight for any woman in the world beſides.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is a rare Coward; we'll have excellent ſport with him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, you may take your own Election, either fight, be beaten, or forbear coming there.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſince I may take my own choice, I'le take time to conſider of it; I won't reſolve on any thing too haſtily.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: My Lord, you know your own certain mind already, and had as good tell it before you go.

div.stage: Moriphanus offers to go off, and Lucidore takes him by the ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, you are not like to ſtir till you have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, Sir, then I will, becauſe I don't much care if I do.
And now, Sir, I have conſider'd of it, I'le neither ſight nor be beaten for any woman, as long as there's God's plenty of them in the world. Here's a quarter and a do about a woman indeed!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then you'l come no more there?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No that I won't: But what if ſhe comes to me? I warrant you'l go and challenge her too, and fight with her: you think ſhe's to be won by fighting; but, alas, you are deceiv'd, ſhe is not to be won by the Blade; there's a Bill in the caſe which you know not of, which will prevail before the Sword.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But it ſhan't be long before I know the Bill, and the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But what if I will not tell you? am I bound to tell you all that I know?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, not if you'l fight, but you muſt otherwiſe, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You ſhould not need to preſs me thus to fight, had I not made a vow, the laſt man I kill'd in ſeven years, never to anſwer not make a challenge to any man living: no, you ſhould have no cauſe to call upon me twice.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: To run away.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You'd find I would not be abus'd. O that the time were expir'd! you put me into ſuch a rage, that my paſſion muſt vent it ſelf ſome way.

div.stage: Falls a crying, and turns to Grac.

sp.speaker: Graculus,
sp.p: did'ſt never hear that fighting was Phyſical?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Not I, upon my life, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then if thou dar'ſt take my word for it, it is.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But Sir, what makes you weep?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My vow, Graculus, my vow!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your pretence of a vow, is but an excuſe for your Cowardice.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why, in troth, my Lord, if I were as you, I would fight, and for once break a vow made in cold blood, now your courage is ſo ſpur'd and chaf'd with theſe quarrolling Lords.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me ſee, let me ſee. Hum; no way (Studies. left to break this rotten Engagement, and fight?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, you may eaſily break it where 'tis rotten.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you can find none in your Conſcience, ſend but for half a dozen Advocates, give 'em double fees, and they'l find you one in theirs, and a point in Law to make it good.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If it can be done by them; I'le make my own Conſcience do't as well, and ſave me that charges: And ſuppoſe I am reſolv'd to fight, there's more to be conſider'd of then juſt that; there's time, weapon, and place.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That you ſhall have the liberty to Elect.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well then, let me conſider; as to the time I can't do it this ſeven years, I am ſure, I have buſineſs for every particular day; and if I appoint ten or twenty years hence, and am call'd to take my place of Honor in the other world before, then you'l ſay, I am not a man of my word; a Knave, a Cheat, a Raſcal, or ſome ſuch thing: Therefore it ſhall be a Duel in the other world.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O brave, my Lord, that will do rarely: But who ſhall be your Seconds?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Hold thy prating: I'le nominate my ſelf who ſhall be both our Seconds: He ſhall have Alexander the
Great, and the Maid of Orleance, and I'le have Sampſon, and William the Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I, my Lord, do ſo; ſtand to your hold; for you may lend Sampſon, if you liſt, one of your Jaw-bones, and then he ſhall fight with Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you will fight, or dare fight, fight now for your Miſtris: we'll find another quarrel to exerciſe your courage in th'other world.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I tell you I will not fight a ſtroak till the time appointed; ſo I may have ſome cowardly dog-trick or other put upon me: I'le have all that ever liv'd from the Creation, to that day, ſtand by when I Duel, to ſee that there is fair play. And ſo no more of that: I'm in great haſt, and muſt leave your angry Honors.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Mor.

div.head: Scene 8. Enter Melyent reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Lotharicus dead! thou haſt bravely done,
And juſtly the reward of Death haſt won;
Which thou ſhalt have; but e're thou com'ſt at it,
Thou muſt another Tragedy commit.
My Fortune now is almoſt made ſecure,
There is but one blow more it can endure:
Euryalus, thou muſt not live to be
An interpoſing Cloud' twixt that and me:
For e're my greatneſs ſhall be ſo withſtood,
I'le make my paſſage through a Sea of Blood.
My Soul is with too towring hopes poſſeſt,
To be by thoughts of Conſcience now ſuppreſt:
Nor ſhall Euryalus prolong the date,
VVhich I have given for his dying Fate.

div.head: Scene 9. Enter Euryalus in diſguize, and Deſha.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Pray go tell your Lady here is a Gentleman has buſineſs of importance with her, and deſires to tell it her in private.

sp.speaker: Deſh.
sp.p: I ſhall acquaint her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: All things are in this Kingdome as plentiful and proſperous, as if that none but Saints inhabited it.
But ſurely Sin's infection is grown high,
VVhen Monarchs once their Souls with Murders Dye:
For they are Suns on which the Subjects gaze,
To gather rules for mannaging their ways.
How ſtrictly then are they to Virtue ty'd,
VVho, by Example, are a Nations Guide?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Brother! dear Euryalus, how—He

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Thou'rt grown unworthy of ſuch kindneſh now.
It is not love has brought me back, but hate.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Oh Heaven, what have I done to make you ſay't!

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What have you not, could baſe and barb'rous be?
Murder Lotharicus, diſhonour me.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I kill Lotharicus! Heaven knows that I,
Falſe as he is, to ſave his life would die.
For worlds I would not live that grief to know.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What Devil helps thee to diſſemble ſo?
Has that black Favorite of Hell's deſign,
Taught thee this virtue with the reſt to joyn?
Was't not enough you did his life betray,
To ſerve your pride made that be took away;
But with your curs'd malicious blaſting breath,
Strive, in his Fame, to give him ſecond death?
Or, did your Soul ſuch ſharp reprovements give
To your falſe heart, that fear'd to let him live?
Could bubling Greatneſs thy ambition ſwell
To ſuch a height, to ſend thee Poſt to Hell.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I have no guilt, I hope, can bring me there,
But in my Grave you'l throw me by diſpair;
For nothing's left to make me wiſh to ſtay,
If my Lotharicus be took away.
Where he in aſhes is, I'd rather be,
Then here poſſeſs the whole worlds Monarchy.
Thy deadlieſt ſtroak thou now haſt given, Fate;
Marcelia's ſtrength cannot ſupport the weight.
In life I nothing now but horrors ſee,
Since earth is rob'd (Lotharicus) of thee.
All it poſſeſs'd of great and brave, now lies
Gluttonous Death, thy malice Sacrifice:
Since thou his Noble life refus'd to ſpare,
No longer this unhappy one forbear.
I court thy cold imbraces to this breaſt,
For till my ſoul's with his, I ne're ſhall reſt:
And ſure it can't be long before it be,
Since grief and love both ſtrive to ſet it free.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What's this I ſee? certain I'm in a dream;
Falſhood cannot pretend ſuch high extream.
Marcelia, what to judge I do not know,
Since for his death you ſo much paſſion ſhow.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Judge what you will, my Innocence you'l prove,
By that which quickly will your doubts remove.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Then 'tis that dev'liſh Melynet has laid
That plot, which both his Love and Life betraid.
Treacherous Serpent! Monſter of Mankind!
How could thy Noble Blood ſuch tincture find?
Or thy falſe Soul permit thee to divide,
Two hearts which thou did'ſt find ſo ſtrongly ty'd?
For he did for thy change ſuch trouble ſhow,
As nothing but the higheſt flame could know:
His daily wiſhes were, he might expire,
Becauſe he had out-liv'd Marcelia's fire.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Add, add no more, leaſt reaſon quit this place,
And after that, then this be left by Grace.
I am a Mortal, and no more can ſhow
Of power, in my paſſons overthrow.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: To raiſe thy miſeries I do not deſign.
But I would have thee th'top of Honor climb:
Refuſe the King, then do thy Honor right,
To ſhew that greatneſs dazles not thy ſight;
For his conſent was given to the fact;
And marrying him thou wilt his guilt contract.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I'le ſooner be to a dead body joyn'd,
Then ever in his guilty Arms confin'd:
No, no, Euryalus, his Crown can't take,
That Love away, his Virtues could not ſhake:
From one revenge I gave him my conſent,
And from this ſecond I'le his hopes prevent.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Dear, dear Marcelia, my moſt Noble part,
Thou mak'ſt me jealous of thy generous heart.
Lotharicus will ſurely in his Grave,
Rejoyce to ſee thou art ſo true and brave,
For Melynet, wh' has rais'd him ſelf ſo great,
By ſtrangling Virtue in it's proper Seat;
I'le truſt this Arm to find me out the way,
The price of Murder in his heart to pay.
The King is by that awful name ſecute;
Subjects are bound what they do to endure.
Heav'n reſerves it ſelf the puniſhing them:
They are not here to give account to men.
Who ſtrikes at them, Divinity gives a blow;
Whoſe Vice-Roys Monarchs all are here below.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A very likely matter indeed, that ſhe ſhould refuſe to marry me becauſe I would not fight for her: No, no, ſhe is not ſo ungodly, and loves me better then to deſire I ſhould venture my life: Beſides, I never told her, or ſaid ſuch a word, that I would kill my ſelf for her, or kill any man for her, nor go to the Devil for her; and thou mayſt be ſure ſhe does not look that I ſhould do more then my bargain.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, are you ſo ignorant, I mean unknowing, to ſet any bounds to your promiſe to a Miſtris? Why, you ſhould run full ſpeed unto all you thought ſhe would have, or could poſſibly deſire, to make her think you were one mad, and dying for her; and when y' have won her, and are married, then you may do as moſt married men does, pace them in the performance, or quite bed-rid them; or if you will keep in the rank of the beſt Husbands, why then you muſt make your Wife Parſon of your Courting, Vows, and Promiſes, and give her the Tyths; for when they have run out of their wits ſo far, that it cannot keep'em from going to Service, 'tis fit they know they have a Maſter.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Servant, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, Madam, I am not ſo happy to have it ſo yet. Was not that well anſwer'd, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: It was anſwer'd like your ſelf, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do you obſerve, Arcaſia? The verieſt Fool that is can expect Government if he marries.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: And well they may: It is but reaſonable, that thoſe Fools that can get into that Authority, ſhould govern thoſe Fools that gave it. Don't you think it fit in judgment, that the leaſt Fool ſhould rule the greater?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'le not ſpeak my Opinion to the prejudice of my intention. But, my Lord, pray what gives me the honor of this early viſit? for I had hardly din'd when you came.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'le tell you a thing, but I would not have you trouble your ſelf about it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Truly, that high affliction that put me into this habit, was ſo great, that it muſt be ſomething extraordinary can move me now to any ſenſe of ſorrow.—But let me know it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am very much afraid this will; and for all I came on purpoſe to tell it you, and 'tis very fit you ſhould know it, yet you ſhall not know it, unleſs you ſwear, and give me your hand, you will not grieve about it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I cannot promiſe you it ſhall not trouble my heart, if it ſhould concern you: but I will not make the leaſt ſigh of it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why that's it now; it does concern me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, if it does concern you never ſo much, I will keep my word, ſince you have ingag'd me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then to tell you the truth, the ſhort and the long is, it was ten thouſand to one you had never ſeen me again: I was ſet upon, and like to bin kill'd about you; my Man can tell here; I brought him on purpoſe to juſtifie it, if you ſhould not believe it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: In troth I cannot but be extremely merry to hear the danger is over. Lord, I do but think what a pickle I ſhould have bin in, if I had known it when it was, by the joy I find now for the eſcape.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: He was in a pickle enough for himſelf and you too, I'le ſwear for him, Madam: the thoughts of never ſeeing you again wrought ſtrangely upon him, to my knowledge, in that little time; that fear made him go lighter from the Gentlemen in perſonal weight, then he met them.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: It ſeems there was very fowl play; two againſt one.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, who were thoſe Cowards?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore, and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the humors, I ever knew, to forbid other Suitors, and not offer to come a woing himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, I ſhall always be in danger of my life till we are married; every one will have a fling at it, thinking you love me beſt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I would not marry you now you have told me this, for all the world: for hitherto they have only intended to kill you, becauſe as yet you have only intended to marry: but if you ſhould marry in earneſt, they'l kill you ſo too, for they'l grow deſperate when they're out of all hopes: So I ſee plainly I ſhall be a Widdow preſently; my Vail will be no ſooner off, but on again; and to looſe you ſo ſoon, would quite break my heart.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Truly I believe it would; for the thoughts of it almoſt breaks mine already.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, now I think of it, it was told for certain by my Nativity, that my ſecond Husband ſhould be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But are you to have no more?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O, yes, yes!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then I'le be the third; I'le tarry with all my heart for you, till the danger be over, that is to come upon the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: There's a far worſe, and more un-gentleman-like death threatens my third and fourth, then all the reſt; for the one will be hang'd, and the other—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What will become of him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why, without any ceremony, he is to hang himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I had rather be him then any of the others, becauſe I know mine own natural averſion againſt death, and ſhould have this comfort, at leaſt, that I ſhould not be forc'd to die againſt my mind, as long as I was to be my own Executioner.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That's a thing indeed, my Lord, would make the danger much leſs; but if I may adviſe you, run not the hazard, you know not what a good Wife may tempt you to.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd, I love him ſo well, he ſhall never while I live get my conſent, to put him into the danger of it, nor my ſelf into the poſſibility of ſo much grief.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, meer love of one another I ſee makes us both reſolve never to marry together: Now there's not one of a hundred does ſo I believe:—
For all that, Graculus, I ſhall never put her out of my mind.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: No, my Lord, if you ſtay here; no man can forget a dead Wife but by change of Air; therefore you muſt needs go and travel, to get you a freſh appetite to a new affection.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Will that do it, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I marry will it Sir, I warrant you; 'tis a receipt Probatum.—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: 'Tis true as I tell thee; Peregrine is taken with Arcaſia, and has made an invitation to thy Widdow, and her, to the Gardens; he intends to give them an entertainment there.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Prethee let us be his unbidden Gueſts for once, we'll not be in his debt, I am reſolv'd I will ſend in my diſh.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: A match, a match.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Lotharicus death, Sir, gives an abſolute ſecurity to your love.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It does inlarge my hopes of having now the full poſſeſſion of Marcelia's heart; but ſtill a gallant man muſt be lamented; I, and my Kingdome both, may juſtly mourn his death.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No doubt, Sir, he does deſerve it; and did not your Majeſties concern ballance my ſorrow, the loſs of ſuch a friend would cauſe much greater trouble in my Soul. But all things, Sir, does, and ſhall ſtill give place unto my duty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I doubt thee not in any thing, my Melynet. But does Marcelia know yet of Lotharicus death?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, Sir; but intend ſhe ſhall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Prethee do; for I ſhall long to know how ſhe does take it. 'Tis natural in Lovers to be curious in the ſearch of that which gives them the higheſt troubles: and when there is a real wanting cauſe, our jealouſies do commonly create us ſome ſuppoſitions; and mine does ſtrongly work in doubts, for all her ſeeming kindneſſes and promiſes, they're all but empty nothings to that paſſion her heart once had, and I fear ſtill conceals for dead Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I cannot think it Sir: but I will ſoon inform my ſelf, and give your Majeſty ſatisfaction.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Peregrine, Perilla, and Arcaſia, in a Garden. A Table ſet out with ſeveral Meats and Wine: with Attendance.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I could wiſh I had given my Lord Lucidore an invitation.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: I wiſh you had, for he is moſt excellent company.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And much your ſervant, I am ſure, Madam; he is one of your ſecret Lovers that has not yet made diſcovery of his flame; but it will not be long before the fire break out, I am confident.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I do not think he is conſtant enough, to think and ſay all at one time, he loves.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Indeed, he does not ſeem to be of a humor, that his heart ſhould be in any danger of ever being made a womans priſoner.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Would he were here to anſwer for himſelf: I could find of my heart to ſend one of my Boys to find him out.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: You'l put him upon 24 hours ſearch then: When he goes out in a morning, by report, he is commonly loſt all that day to any Enquirers. But perhaps his uſual curioſity of ſeeing the Beauties, may bring him hither anone.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Why, does he take ſuch pains to be rid of his liberty, to come here to ſeek for a Conqueror?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
No, Madam; it was his Opinion of his own invincible ſtrength made him ſo bold to attempt the danger: He us'd to ſwear, as long as Cupid was a Child, he fear'd him not; he had not ſo poor a ſpirit to be worſted by a Boy: If he liv'd ſo long till he came to be a man, which he had bin theſe two thouſand years a coming to,
and not one jot the forwarder yet, he would then ſtand upon his guard againſt him.

sp.speaker: Muſ.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore ſent us hither to give your Lordſhip a new Leſſon.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I thank him; I wiſh his Lordſhip had come himſelf too.

div.stage: The Muſick (eſpying the Boys coming at the other end of the Stage with a diſh) begin to play.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis very hot, it burns my fingers; and 'tis very heavy too: we'll ſet it down and dance a little risk.

div.stage: Enter a Mercury with a great Chaſi • -diſh of Coals; reaches up the diſh, ſets it thereon.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Why, what have you done Boys? the diſh is quite cold: you forget you carry'd your Lords Love, which is a Native of Freezland.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, can it be cold already?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Cold already? I, hot and cold, and cold and hot, a hundred times over, to a hundred ſeveral Ladies.

div.stage: Takes up the Coals, and blows under it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray ſtay a little, and we'll go fetch ſome Bellows, and make it boil.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Be quick.

div.stage: Enter preſently again with two more Boys, each with Bellows. They dance with Mercury in the middle, with the diſh and fire in his hand, every one by turns blowing under the Diſh: The dance ended, Exeunt Boys. Mercury comes up with the diſh to the Table.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore preſents this to you, Madam.

div.stage: Perilla opens the diſh, there is the form of a Hart made with wings, in it a Copy of Verſes directed to the Incomparable Widow. (They all laugh extremely.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: What is in it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Nothing but a copy of Verſes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: But I am much taken with the Caſe they came in; I have a great conceit all mens hearts are thus provided, they are ſo ſoon here, and there, and every where.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: All mens are not, Madam; ſome are fix'd.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That is then where the Ladies get to them by ſome more then common device, and clip their wings. But Perilla, the Verſes▪ we will participate as far forth as the hearing the Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.l: Widdow, Faith I will tell thee true▪
My heart's inflam'd, and 'tis by you
But my paſſion will decay.
If you make too long delay.
Flames that with moſt vigor burn,
Sooneſt into aſhes turn:
Then reſolve, and quickly too,
Shall I ſtay, or bid adieu?
Fooliſh Lovers that do place
All their pleaſures in one face;
Let them for favors long expect,
I ſoon will have, or ſoon neglect:
This is not common Courtſhips way▪
But ſince I lov'd you 'tis a day:
And if you cannot pay the ſcore,
Y'are poor, and I will truſt no more.
I've ways my Fortunes to undo▪
Without the help of lending you:
I can both drink, and game, and ſwear,
Does this not tempt you 〈◊〉 tell me fair.
Yet I'l a kinder Husband be,
Than thoſe that ſin more ſecretly.
But if you proudly now deny
To love me, Faith I will not dy.

div.stage: Enter Lucidore with Three Trumpeters, Almeric ſtanding at a diſtance as not to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sound a Charge.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Why you make Love in open court, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I do ſo, Madam, to prevent the ſcandal of the world, which would go near elſe to ſay, I ſtole your conſent, if you and I ſhould marry.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: But why did you make your Trumpeters ſound a Charge?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is the aſſault of my Love againſt your Liberty, unleſs you will come preſently to party, and give me ſome hopes of an honorable peace betwixt us: nay, I have began my war in perfect form, I have ſent two or three Heralds to proclaim it in the Market-place.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Yet, for all that, you have not done like a fair Enemy, to ſurprize me without any knowledge of ſuch an intention.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All ſtratagems are allow'd of, Madam. Could you expect I would give you notice to fortific your ſelf againſt my ſiege? Faith I'ad bin an ignorant Souldier then indeed.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: No, my Lord, ſhe could not in juſtice; for if you had, ſhe would have ſo ſtrengthen'd her ſelf with an Army of Reaſons of her own and from her Friends, that her heart would have prov'd another Candy, impregnable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And quite tire out the Turkiſh Emperors Conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
But, I hope my fair Widow will not be ſo cruel to wrack my expectations ſo long; for if ſhe ſhould, I have no more to confeſs than I will confeſs now, that is, that I love her infinitely, paſſionately, unexpreſſibly, as much as ever any man did or will love any of the Sex: I do indeed, Dear Widow! but now if you ſhould heep me in a great deal of pain by making a Chancery-ſuit of our Affections,
'tis ten to one but I ſhall rather deny all this truth again, than endure ſuch an endleſs torment.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Faith, Widow, you muſt now reſolve: this new faſhion'd ſuiter will have his alms or his anſwer quickly.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I, Madam, you muſt needs tell my Lord what you'l do, you don't know what an injury you may do him, by keeping him long in ſuſpenſe; for if his heart ſhould have taken poſt to any other place, how do you think his body ſhould know where to find it?

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: We'l petition the King to introduce here the Engliſh Law, that is, if he loſes it between ſun and • un, the County muſt make it good.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That is if it were ſtollen, Madam.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Well, if it has run away, or loſt it ſelf, then he muſt have it cry'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Never think of theſe ways to baffle me out of my Heart, Madam, in plain terms you have ſtoln it; and if you ſtir out of this Garden without reſtitution, or my conſent to keep it, hang me if I ſend not a Hue and Cry after you.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: It ſeems, my Lord, you are very ſharp ſet to my Eſtate; if you poſſeſt that, I believe you would eaſily bequeath my perſon for a Legacy to my next Heir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, that you ſhould think ſo! As if a Rich Miſtris were to be prefer'd before a Miſtris Rich. Do you think I am ſo ill bred to diſplace your Title ſo, to put money before it? No, it ſhall never take the precedency. It is as much as I deſire that I am certain it is one of your attendants: for where Marriage is made, and that a ſervant to neither party, there is always to be ſure but beggarly houſe-keeping, and I love good company as my life.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p:
Well, I will not injure my wit ſo much to take ſeven years conſideration to make up at laſt a bad bargain: as if a great deal of time were requiſite to undo ones ſelf
in, when a quarter of an hour will ſerve turn as well; and precipitated indiſcretions always will admit of more excuſe, than premeditated follies. This gives you nay conſent ſo ſoon, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I care not from whence the line come, ſo long as it draws to my Center: I'l accept it good or bad, according to the old Rule of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Well, once within this month we ſhall both repent it, after the Parſon has ty'd us together.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If we do, and the worſt come to the worſt, 'tis but one of us making a journey into the other world, and unmarrying our ſelves: and when it comes, we'l have fair play, draw who ſhall go.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: A very juſt bargain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nothing will break your agreement then I ſee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But firſt we'l try to break each others heart.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Lotharicus in a Diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: It is ſome pleaſure ſince I could nor dy, at leaſt to think that I ſhall now revenge my wrongs my ſelf, on my intended Murtherer: and by giving him his merited Death, puniſh the falſe Marcelia too:
sp.l: And in the bud of her wiſh'd Queenſhips honor,
Nip h • r ſupport, that treacherous Favorite from her.
She little think Lotharicus doth live,
So great a ruine to her hopes to give.
Here he muſt paſs, and in this place I'l ſtay,
And make Death complement him in the way.

div.stage: Enter Melynet with two boys, Lotharicus meets him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Boys go where I bid you.—Ha! what's that comes there?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: An injur'd Lover brought by his deſpair.— Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That's falſe I'm ſure, I know thou ſayſt not true.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: His Ghoſt is riſe to give thy crimes their due:
Villain! I live and with this ſword will ſhow,
In my revenge, whether't be true or no:
I all my wrongs upon thy heart will write.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No more of words, but let us to't, and ſight.
Boaſt not before we do the vict'ry try,
Perhaps it may prove your own lot to dy.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I could have made my ſelf of that ſecure,
But that my Courage Treach'ry can't endure.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I'l thank thy Courage and the debt will pay,
By taking thy unhappy life away.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Fall on then.
—Ha! methinks you back do ſtart,
As if my kindneſs touch'd you to the heart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What it has done I ſoon will make thee find:
What think you now Sir, are you paid in kind?

div.stage: Enter Valaſco, Peregrine, they draw and come between them.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Hold this is no good exerciſe.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The beſt that can be, Sir, to us.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How, Lotharicus!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What wonder's this? and fighting with his ſo beloved friend my Lord Melynet?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The wonder is far greater that occaſion'd it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord Melynet, I am glad we have prevented the hazard of your life to farther Revenge.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have obſtructed me in a Revenge, Which I could curſe you for:—for by preventing Of his Death, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: We'l not take our leaves one of another, we ſhall have opportunity to meet in ſome other place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I have not ſeen Melynet to day: I wonder much he is not come.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Doubtleſs it will not be long before he does attend your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Have you not ſeen Melynet, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, and it pleaſe your Majeſty: I came from him: he is wounded.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How? by what means?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord Lotharicus is return'd in diſguiſe, and has ſet upon him as he was going to Marcelia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou doſt miſtake, Lotharicus is dead I'l aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And pleaſe your Majeſty he has got ſuch favor in the other world to come and live again; for I am ſure it is not half an hour ſince Peregrine and I parted them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Are you ſure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As ſure as my name is Valaſco.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What ſhould the meaning of this be? Go and cauſe him to be brought before me; I'l hear the motion of this bold attempt upon the life of Melynet my ſelf. Are his wounds dangerous?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir, very ſlight: they have both ſome little hurt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sure Lotharicus's jealouſie has cauſ'd this quarrel with Melynet, becauſe he knows I have a value for him, and by that concludes that he has injur'd him to Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And pleaſe your Majeſty, Love from ſo ſtrong an argument may be excuſ'd to grow ſuſpicious.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p:
I am come to tell thee ſtrange news, Marcelia; Lotharicus is alive in the Town: he has wounded Melynet,
and is a Priſoner for it by the Kings command, and is to be brought before him to the Court: the buſineſs is made very foul, as if he had ſurpriz'd him cowardly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a compound of joy and ſorrow have you given me? Poor Lotharicus! thou wilt find a cruel Judg: I fear they muſt, by heightning thy guilt, help to abate their own. I'l go to the Court my ſelf: and hear his ſentence, and ſhare his ſufferings, if my intereſt cannot take him off; I'l try my power firſt, then ſhow my reſolution.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Thou mak'ſt a generous and brave Reſolve, we both will go together: I'l there diſcover my ſelf, and help to juſtifie my Friend, and if there be occaſion againſt his guilty adverſary. It will be time to go, Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My dear Lotharicus, thou now ſhalt find,
When moſt diſtreſt, Marcelia is moſt kind.

div.head: Scene 8. Enter King, Melynet, and all the Lords, Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am ſorry having ever had ſo great an eſteem of Lotharicus, he ſhould give me cauſe to condemn him for his Raſhneſs: but Reaſon is deſtroy'd in the wiſeſt men, when paſſion does command.—Bring in Lotharicus.

div.stage: Enter Lotharicus with a Guard at one door, and Euryalus and Marcelia at another.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What makes me happy in thy preſence now, Marcelia?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Though 'tis not fit▪ Sir, Women hither come:
Yet I moſt humbly beg to hear his doom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nothing's unfit Marcelia does deſire,
Or of her King, or Servant can require.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: There ſtands my torture greater than I can
Receive from the command or power of man.
She comes to feaſt her pride, onely to ſee,
How much my Paſſion ſtill does fetter me.
Inhumane Woman! loſt to all that ſenſe
Which thy ſoft Sex to ſuff'rers do diſpenſe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What was the cauſe Lotharicus, that arm'd your malice againſt the life of Melynet?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: My injurius, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: In your opinion. Were every man a fitting and allow'd of Judg in's own cauſe, we need not then have Miniſters of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I queſtion not the prudence of conſider'd and allow'd of Laws, Sir; though now I ſought not their aſſiſtance. But, Sir, in my own defence, I humbly do preſent your Majeſty this Paper; which renders me incapable their benefit, and made me ſtrive, by my own hand to take what I can never expect to have by any other means.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How have you forfeited your right in that kind, more than your other fellow-ſubjects?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You'l in that Paper find, Sir.

div.stage: The King reads and changes countenance, grows into fury: turns to Melynet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Traytor! what haſt thou done? is this thy hand? is it? I know it is: wherewith th'haſt ſet the feal of my diſhonor; charge me with the conſent of Murther, and mountain up my promiſes their recompence!—Here, Read it publickly; my brow wears not a guilt ſo dark to keep it in obſcurity, although I ow that intended kindneſs to brave Lotharicus's Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Du-Prette, be ſure and ſpeedy in the death of Lotharicus, the King is impatient till he hears it, he will double thy rewards I promiſed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There's enough.
How durſt thou aſſume the injuring thy Soveraign ſo?

Though I Marcelia lov'd, I never did deſign to buy her favors at the price of all my Honors. By noble ways I bid
thee ſeek to gain me her affection, but not by guilt and treacherous baſeneſs, Villain. The ſhare thy veins has in her blood, gives thee thy life: but never after this day ſee thy incenſed Monarch's face again! But how came you by this Letter, Lotharicus?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Sir, one Philampras, which was hir'd amongſt others, by Du-prette, Melynet's man to aſſaſin me underſtanding by Du-prette's Diſcourſe that he had moneys in his Portmantue, watch'd his opportunity to take it aways and finding this Letter there, thought he ſhould make more advantage by that from my Reward, that his promiſ'd recompence for my Murther: ſo left the money to prevent Duprette's ſudden miſſing of his Paper; and coming with my man to diſcover it, found me as they then ſuppoſed kill'd; but after, on my Recovery, deliver'd it into my hands.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh! how ſeriouſly ought Princes firſt to weigh the lives and ſouls of men, before they draw them to their boſoms! for Favorites that are vitious, are the Cankers of Kings Courts, and eat in their Soveraigns boſoms.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sir!—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold, ſay no more, thy breath's infectious grown And on my Fame has Killing poyſon thrown.
Guard, take him away.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Vain joys of mortal Life! you fly ſo faſt,
Man hardly knows you are, before y' are paſt:
Yet we on you do our affections lay,
As if we here eternally ſhould ſtay.
Honor, thou now doſt give my ſoul a view
Of what I left when firſt I baniſh'd you.
O Virtue! how have I bin led aſtray.
From thy fair paths, into this Lab'rinth way?
I thought my Fortune on a Rock did ſtand.
But Guilts foundation ſtill proves fooliſh ſand.
When man by Crimes does plots for greatneſs lay,
Heav'n juſtly frowns and takes his hopes away.
But though my Life bears characters of ſhame:
My Death ſhall leave behind a better Fame.
They that won't fall, muſt not on danger ſtand;
We carry not our Fates in our own hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Though Love, Lotharicus, did make me be Thy Rival, I was ne'er thy Enemy:
At leſt to take thy life by ways obſcure,
My ſoul ſuch abject thoughts ſcorn to endure.
To witneſs it, I this for thee will do:
Marcelia freely ſhall chuſe me or you.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Marcelia, Sir, cannot diſputethe choice:
Againſt my ſelf your Goodneſs has my voice.
And ſhe long ſince has learn'd to be ſo wiſe,
To leave Lotharicus for ſuch a prize.
Pardon me, Sir, that I am ſad, that ſhe
Found not ſuch motives for her love in me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never more deſir'd than what in you
I did enjoy, when I believ'd you true:
But when by Melynet I was inform'd,
I and my love was for Arcaſia ſcorn'd:
I then ſuch Reaſon had to entertain
So great a Monarch, and ſo high a Flame:
That all I for his Paſſion ſince did do,
Can no condemning cenſure find for you:
Honor and Virtue ſtill have bin my guid,
My Life has ſtrictly to their Rules bin ty'd.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Since Melynet made me ſo falſe appear,
You need not more your actions for to clear:
But ſtill as they juſtly more ſplendid grow,
My heart does more deſpairing ſorrow know.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Which of us two, Madam, ſhall happy be?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heav'n leaves me not to an Election free.
Both ſo deſerve, Sir, that If I ſhould chuſe,
I'd be unjuſt to him I did refuſe.
Oh Gods! what puniſhment do you deſign
Marcelia, that neither muſt be mine!
Love will not let me my Lotharicus leave,
Nor Honor won't permit I him receive.

div.stage: [The King whiſpers to Peregrine▪ Exit Pereg.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To ſhew that I will ſtill be here within,
What I am by my birth, my paſſions King:
My Empire there, by Reaſons power maintain,
As well as to my Crown, new Crowns to gain:
I out of Honor will this Juſtice do,
Againſt my Love, Marcelia give to you▪
Thou art already of her Heart poſſeſt,
And with her Perſon now I'l make thee bleſt.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Sir,—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more oppoſe thy bliſs with gen'rous ſtrife,
May you be happy in each others life:
My heart to my Calinda I'l reſtore,
Whoſe due it was by faith and love before.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: May Fortune ſhowr ſuch Bleſſings on your head,
That over all the World your power be ſpread:
That every Monarch that enjoys a Throne,
May that poſſeſſion from your bounty own.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Now take the Bleſſing which I, Sir, do give,
When you are call'd from hence to Heav'n to live:
And may my Friend prove joys ſo high refin'd,
To equal the vaſt compaſs of his mind.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir, I am come my Duty to expreſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To me Calinda can own nothing leſs;
In publick I my heart away did take▪
And I'l in publick Reſtitution make.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Will can ſtrangely of your Heart diſpoſe,
My Will, as yet, o'r mine no Empire knows.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet it may yours perſwade, and command mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You ſhould not then Marceliaes Love decline.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, you have all Reaſon to expreſs,
As much as you can ſay in ſcorns exceſs:
But Heav'n the greateſt faults that are forgive,
'Tis noble, when we may kill, to let live.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Had you bin ſtill, Sir, to that Maxim true,
I had not then bin ſcorn'd, nor left by you:
When you the life did take of all my joy,
You ſhow'd not the left pity to deſtroy.
But you would have, I find, a Womans breaſt
With more Compaſſion and more Love poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'd have thy Heart again thy Love renew,
Since mine does burn with a freſh Flame to you.
Calinda, with my Life I would redeem.
What I have done, to call back thy eſteem.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Majeſty can ſtrangely overcome,
Scarce wiſh a Victory before 'tis won:
That price my Heart will never let you pay,
Love's Gen'ral there, and yields you up the day

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And if I e'er again that gift abuſe,
May Heav'n all prayers that I make refuſe:
I much admir'd thy Excellence heretofore;
But now Idolater ſhall turn, and thee adore.
I did not think this would have bin the cloſe:
sp.q: Man may deſign, but Heav'n will ſtill diſpoſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: NOw I am ſure, all look that I ſhould ſay
Something like asking pardon for the Play:
With low ſubmiſſion, and I can't tell what:
Excuſe her Writing, Language, and her Plot!
As crafty Poets Guilty cry their Wit,
To make you leſs ſevere in laſhing it.
But, faith, ſhe ſcorns ſuch undermining ways,
Of blowing up your pity into praiſe;
Nor will ſhe do her ſpirit ſo much wrong,
To beg what does not to her brow belong.
She ſays, they're fools force Fate, before they be
Reſolv'd to meet with any Destiny.
But, this revenge ſhe's ſure to have on thoſe,
They'l Cowards be esteem'd that give her blows.
Which ſtrangely takes her! knowing that ye must
Be to your Honor, or your Wit unjuſt.
Mark how maliciouſly her ſnares ſh'as laid:
Praiſe or Condemn, you're equally betray'd.
